textAfterTable: *Source: U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics Operations management uses an array of concepts and methods to maximize an organization's efficiency. Those pursuing careers in this field prepare themselves by enrolling in degree programs that teach these concepts and methods. There are, for example, bachelor's degree programs in operations management that include courses in such topics as project management, manufacturing planning, supply-chain management and quality control. Some employers require candidates to have advanced degrees, such as a master's degree in operations management. This degree program may include advanced coursework in statistical methods, strategic management and financial management. In addition to formal education, some positions, such as management consultant, require considerable experience. Some employers require applicants to have experience in a particular industry or area of expertise, like manufacturing or healthcare. Operations management professionals may also seek professional certification. For example, an industrial-production manager may obtain the Certified Technology Manager designation, which is offered by the Association of Technology, Management and Applied Engineering (www.atmae.org). Career Options Obtaining a degree in operations management can lead to becoming an operations manager which involves coordinating and improving the activities of a variety of types of companies. Another career option is to pursue a career as an industrial production manager for a particular manufacturing organization. A third career possibility would be to become a management consultant, providing advice to companies on improving their operations.
